newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - U.S. debt vols pressured by time decay.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - U.S. debt vols pressured by time decay.

text.p: Implied volatilities for shorter-dated U.S. fixed-income options softened late in Friday's shortened session, under pressure from time decay over the long weekend, dealers said.
"We're going into the weekend mode now...so volatilities are obviously dropping," said a Treasury bond trader for a brokrage firm at the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT).
He added, however, that T-bond volatilities had briefly popped higher in mid-morning when the underlying bond market started sliding from early highs.
"We had a little bit of action this morning when it looked as if we (bond futures) were going to stay down and break to the downside," he said.
But before long, March T-bond futures found support in the mid-110 area and bounced back above Thursday's settlement, causing bids for options to back off, he said.

Implied volatility for February T-bond futures options on CBOT was off 0.2 point at 7.8 percent in late trade. March volatility was holding relatively well, virtually unchanged from Thursday's close at 9.5 percent.
Traders said there were a number of 1,000-lot trades in the bond options pit but overall volume was moderate.
T-bond trade at the CBOT and Eurodollar contracts at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange will be closed on Monday due to the Martin Luther King Jr Day holiday.
At the shorter end of the yield curve, volatilities for CME Eurodollar futures options were generally easier.
Implied volatilities for June, September and December contracts were off 0.1-0.2 point each at 12.1, 15.0 and 16.4 percent respectively.
Among the largest deals, a European firm was seen selling 2,000 lots of 93.75 March 1998 straddles and a commercial firm bought 2,000 of front-March 94.00/94.25 put spread.
An investment bank was said to have traded a total of 4,000 legs of June 94.00/94.25 squash -- buying 94.25 calls and selling 94.00 puts.
"Volume is decent but volatilities are down because there's not that much activity really," a brokerage firm trader at the CME Eurodollar pit.
